channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Donald Trump is FINALLY pictured wearing a mask during private tour of Michigan Ford plant
item.description: President Trump defied Michigan's mandatory face covering policy and toured a Ford Motor factory with no mask even though the company's executive chairman asked him to put on one.

item.title: Police hunting missing 16-year-old Louise Smith find a body
item.description: Police have found a body in a woodland area of Havant, Hampshire, in the search for 16-year-old Louise Smith, who went missing nearly two weeks ago on May 8.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Thousands flout 'no staying' rules at seaside
item.description: Fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections are growing after yesterday's 82F heatwave brought scores of people to beaches in Southend, Bournemouth and Newquay.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Millions Clap For NHS Carers and key workers
item.description: Now in its ninth week, the Clap for Carers has seen people across the country take to their doorsteps and balconies to show their appreciation for the efforts of those on the frontline during the pandemic.

item.title: Beam me up, Elon! William Shatner tweets offer to hop aboard historic NASA-Space X flight
item.description: William Shatner is itching to return to the final frontier - this time on board Crew Dragon capsule as it is set to send US astronauts to space from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on Wednesday.

item.title: HALF of coronavirus antibody finger-prick tests are unreliable, study of nine finds
item.description: Four of nine coronavirus antibody rapid finger prick tests examined by ABC News and the Mayo Clinic failed to meet the researchers' medical standards for accuracy and performance.

item.title: Business chiefs and MPs call for quick exit from lockdown as new coronavirus cases plunge
item.description: Conservative former leader Iain Duncan Smith said: 'We need to move fast. The threat facing us now, outweighing coronavirus, is that of a failing economy.'

item.title: Bomber like a startled stallion: How the Lancaster was more than just an aircraft
item.description: John Nichol describes visiting the RAF Museum at Hendon in the company of Ron Needle, 93, a former rear gunner in a Lancaster bomber crew. The Lancaster was, and is, more than just an aircraft.

item.title: Colleagues of PC Keith Palmer reveal how concerns about terror attack at Parliament were ignored
item.description: PC Ian Grant (pictured) was a member of the unit guarding the Palace of Westminster. He raised security concerns shared by fellow PCs guarding the perimeter of the Houses of Parliament.

item.title: Kate Garraway joins Clap for Carers as husband remains in ICU
item.description: The Good Morning Britain presenter, 53, beamed as she stood in the street alongside Darcey, 14, and Billy, 10, during the weekly salute on Thursday.

item.title: Matt Hancock squirms over delayed roll-out of crucial NHS coronavirus app
item.description: Speaking at the daily Downing Street coronavirus press conference, Mr Hancock appeared to try to minimise the critical nature of the app, even though experts said it is crucial.

item.title: Scientists identify group of hunter-gatherers in Siberia as ancestors of first North Americans
item.description: Archeologists discovered genetic links between the remains of a 14,000 year-old Siberian and Native American populations, some of which are believed to have migrated across the Bering Strait.

item.title: JAN MOIR: Hey, Steve Coogan, get down off that moral high ground!
item.description: JAN MOIR: Steve Coogan (pictured) is the latest rich celebrity to use the furlough scheme for his own ends. The comedian has furloughed some staff at his home.

item.title: Elon Musk replies 'no problem' when told it will take 10,000 nukes to terraform Mars
item.description: A Russian space executive has questioned Elon Musk's plan to use nukes in order to terrafom Mars, saying it will take 10,000 missiles. However, the SpaceX CEO responded 'no problem.'

item.title: Hope for coronavirus testing breakthrough
item.description: Matt Hancock revealed ministers are trialling an on-the-spot test to tell patients if they have the virus in just 20 minutes - up from the current average of two days.

item.title: Bot-hunter tool finds nearly half of tweets discussing 'reopen America' are from internet crawlers
item.description: The trend of 'reopen America' has gained traction on Twitter, but experts find nearly half of the tweets are fueled by bots. Of the top 50 influential retweeters, 82 percent are bots.

item.title: Premier League star's girlfriend 'caught smuggling stun gun and cosh through Kent airport'
item.description: She is said to have burst into tears when confronted by Border Force guards at London Biggin Hill Airport, Kent, after flying in from Europe on Sunday night.

item.title: Coronavirus: Unions says infected staff could sue headteachers
item.description: A letter has been sent by unions to headteachers last night reminding them of their obligations under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974.

item.title: One in 10 charities 'may go bust in six months' due to the coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Sir Stephen Bubb, director of Charity Futures, suggested there are 'too many' non-profit and voluntary organisations and that more should look to merge together.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Boris Johnson drops NHS foreign workers charge
item.description: Boris Johnson declared the levy will be dropped after senior Tories complained it was 'immoral' that those on the frontline of the coronavirus battle were being forced to pay.

item.title: Trump wants to see Elon Musk's SpaceX rocket's manned takeoff
item.description: President Trump expressed that he was interested in going to Florida next week to watch Elon Musk's SpaceX rocket blast off with NASA astronauts from American soil for the first time.

item.title: How the famous have changed their hair colour during lockdown
item.description: With hair salons closed and make-up artists banished from duty, FEMAIL takes a look at the public figures and celebs who have switched up their hair colour since lockdown.

item.title: Mail Force delivers PPE for care home run by nuns
item.description: The 36 residents at the Presentation Sisters Care Centre in Derbyshire - many of whom are in their 80s and 90s, including several retired nuns - are being helped to keep safe, thanks to Mail Force.

item.title: Earth's magnetic field is WEAKENING between Africa and South America, and malfunctioning satellites
item.description: ESA has made a shocking discovery - the Earth's magnetic field is weakening between South American and Africa. Experts suggest it is a sign our planet is heading to a pole reversal.

item.title: How dare unions use my children to score political points, asks father-of-three STEPHEN ROBINSON
item.description: As the father of three state-educated children - one of them aged seven - I find it difficult to forgive Mary Bousted for dismissing younger children as 'mucky', writes STEPHEN ROBINSON.

item.title: Prince William voices concern about the impact lockdown on children's mental health
item.description: In a video call to care providers, the Duke of Cambridge said he was particularly concerned about the issue, despite families attempting to 'muddle' their way through.

item.title: Irish reporter signs off TV package on outdoor swimming with quip as country eases out of lockdown
item.description: RTÉ presenter Paul O'Flynn made a splash as he ended his report from Dublin's Forty Foot on Wednesday afternoon where bathers were enjoying their first swim since lockdown began.

item.title: Who is the star in the mask? How many can you recognise behind their PPE?
item.description: The coronavirus has resulted in more people wearing protective face masks, including celebrities. As they hide their faces, can you work out who's who?

item.title: Dozens of animals die as blaze tears through a pet shop in Kent
item.description: Six fire engines rushed to Cuddles n Bubbles in Sheerness at around 5pm on Thursday after pedestrians saw smoke through the windows.

item.title: Kate Middleton joins Prince William on Zoom call to thank social care workers across UK
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were seen playing Bingo with residents at a care home as they spoke to frontline workers during a Zoom call today.

item.title: Prince Harry will have to queue for California driving licence
item.description: The Duke of Sussex has a long checklist to go through as he settles into his new life in Los Angeles with wife Meghan Markle and son Archie.

item.title: How Eton became a hotel for heroes opening its doors to key workers who can't see their families
item.description: Nicola Smith hasn't been home for more than eight weeks. A single mum, she hasn't been able to hug her ten-year-old daughter in all that time or see her own mother.

item.title: Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead GUILTY in college admissions scandal
item.description: Lori Loughlin and her husband Mossimo Giannulli have changed their plea to guilty in the college bribery admission scandal.

item.title: Welsh doctors were desperate to deliver the first baby on the NHS in tribute to founder
item.description: Edna May Rees prepared to deliver her seventh child three minutes before midnight on the night of July 4, 1948 in hopsital west Wales. She was the first woman to give birth on the NHS.

item.title: Heartwarming moment man and pet donkey cry as they are reunited following COVID-19 lockdown in Spain
item.description: A Facebook video went viral Monday after Ismael Fernández reunited with his pet donkey Baldomera at the family farm in the southern Spanish city of Malaga.

item.title: My father's swear words were 'Laura' and 'Ashley': SHELLEY KLEIN shares her childhood home
item.description: Shelley Klein in her memoir The See-Through House reveals life as a teenager growing up inside a house in High Sunderland in the Scottish Borders that had no interior doors.

item.title: A dark, rich history of coffee (with a bitter after-taste): The bean that took over the world
item.description: The book focuses largely on one plantation owner in El Salvador and his family since 1889, which has its share of exploitation and brutality. Billions of cups of coffee are drunk around the world each year.

item.title: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN on the lockdown dividing Britain
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: While key workers, from NHS staff to bus drivers, are doing their best to keep the show on the road, millions more are treating the corona crisis as a paid holiday.

item.title: Steve Coogan has furloughed staff his £4m home - telling YOU to pick up the bill, writes RICHARD KAY
item.description: RICHARD KAY: His latest film, the aforementioned Greed, about a billionaire fashion tycoon, has been described as a thinly veiled satire on the bombastic retailer Sir Philip Green

item.title: Coronavirus US: Former White House butler dies at 91
item.description: Wilson Roosevelt Jerman, who died on Friday, was one of the longest serving employees at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave, beginning his five-and-a half-decade career in 1957 as a cleaner.

item.title: Amazon pushes Prime Day to September as it returns to pre-pandemic levels
item.description: Amazon's Prime Day will now take place in September, the Wall Street Journal reports, as the company begins to open up shipments to accept non-essential items.

item.title: Eight-foot Rome sinkhole reveals 27BC Pantheon paving stones
item.description: An eight-foot deep sinkhole opened up on a street in front of the Pantheon in Rome, revealing several ancient paving stones dating as far back as 27BC, when the structure was first built.

item.title: 15 men compete to impregnate woman, 41, on Labor of Love
item.description: Hosted by Sex and the City alum Kristin Davis, the show follows Kristy Katzmann as she searches for love and, more importantly, the father of her potential child.

item.title: Zuckerberg says half of Facebook's 50,000 staff can work from home permanently
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg's Facebook livestream feed shut off while he was talking to employees about his prediction that more than half of the company will be working from home permanently by 2030.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: The worst is not over for the monetary system
item.description: As the spread of Covid-19 ramped up in March, markets came close to their own lockdown. It required interventions by central banks on both sides of the Atlantic to stop a credit crunch.

item.title: Dutch court forces woman to delete Facebook photos of grandkids
item.description: A court in the Netherlands made the ruling after a judge decided the case fell under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Pictured: Stock image.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: One in five in London have had infection
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that 17 per cent of people in a sample from London showed signs that they had been infected with the coronavirus already, triple the rate across the UK.

item.title: Donald Trump pulls out of 'open skies' treaty which lets Russia fly over U.S. military sites
item.description: The U.S. announced it would withdraw from the 35-nation Open Skies treaty that permits aerial surveillance flights over participating countries claiming Russia violated its terms repeatedly.

item.title: Coronavirus: One single successful drug unlikely, says scientist
item.description: Martin Landray, professor of epidemiology at Oxford University, said there was an 'extraordinarily' low chance of one of the five drugs being effective on its own. He is co-running the Recovery trial.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell asks judge to move Epstein victim's civil case to New Mexico
item.description: Annie Farmer, 40, has accused Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell of sexually assaulting her at age 16 at the pedophile's Zorro ranch in New Mexico.

item.title: New York couple caught having sex on subway platform
item.description: Shocking footage has emerged of a raunchy couple having sex on the Flushing Avenue subway platform in Brooklyn, New York in plain view of onlookers.

item.title: Woman, 32, stabbed her to death in front of her daughter
item.description: Melissa Belshaw (pictured), 32, suffered 'catastrophic' injuries in a knife attack at her home in Wigan, Greater Manchester, yesterday afternoon. A 36-year-old man has been arrested.

item.title: Horrified golfer whacks his girlfriend with the ball as he tries trick shots with his caddy
item.description: Joost Luiten, 34, accidentally hit girlfriend Melanie-Jane Lancaster with a ball. The Dutch golfer was recording a video catching a club thrown from a caddy standing 1.5m away.

item.title: Navy veteran turned photographer takes portraits of families and artists during Sacramento lockdown
item.description: Rachelle Steele, who served in the military for seven years, has taken images of 25 households after California instituted its shelter-in-place order on March 19.

item.title: The banks offering ZERO interest
item.description: More than 200 High Street banks, including giants like HSBC, have a mere 0.01 per cent interest rate, meaning customers who invest £10,000 will only claw in £1.

item.title: Coronavirus hijacks cells to turn our immune system against us
item.description: A new study has found that coronavirus block genes that prevent the virus from replicating but allow other genes to flood the infection site with immune cells, causing too much inflammation.

item.title: Metal-detecting divers discover luxury watch worth thousands of pounds on sea bed off Corfu
item.description: Stephen Kershaw and another British diver found a luxury Breitling watch, which they estimated is worth thousands hidden underneath a rock on the sea bed off Corfu on May 8.

item.title: Meghan Markle's 'experience as a B-List actress wasn't going to prepare her', royal expert claims
item.description: Despite Meghan, who is currently living in LA, having a successful acting career, royal commentator Katie Nicholl tells 9Honey that her fame wouldn't have helped her navigate her new royal life.

item.title: And now we go to... ROBBIE SAVAGE? Ex-player makes unexpected appearance at No10 press conference
item.description: The former Leicester and Wales ace, 45, highlighted the mental health benefits of grassroots juniors being at least able to receive coaching during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: A new 'reverse solar panel' generates electricity from the shadows
item.description: The shadow-effect energy generator (SEG), developed in Singapore, makes use of the contrast in illumination between lit and shadowed areas to generate electricity.

item.title: Matt Hancock hints coronavirus immunisations could be made COMPULSORY if UK finds a vaccine
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock today left the door open to the UK having a mandatory coronavirus vaccination programme.

item.title: Bees help plants produce flowers faster by nibbling on their leaves
item.description: Bumblebees bite the leaves of flowerless plants to cause intentional damage in such a way that accelerates the production of flowers.

item.title: Crayola launches Colors of the World 24-pack of skin tone crayons
item.description: The Colors of the World pack includes 24 newly-formulated crayons that represent 40 global skin tones. Colors range from light to dark and have three undertones: Rose, Almond, and Golden.

item.title: Coronavirus: Mass gatherings should be avoided until vaccine
item.description: Danish researchers found that with mitigation efforts such as lockdown and quarantine in place, the key to curbing the spread of the disease is to stop 'superspreader' events.

item.title: Coronavirus: Qatar Airways cabin crew will wear HAZMAT suits
item.description: The suits are part of a raft of measures that the Doha-based airline is introducing from Monday (May 25) as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Passengers will receive a modified in-flight service.

item.title: London has recorded fewer than 100 Covid-19 cases a day for a FORTNIGHT
item.description: Data from Public Health England shows that the last time more than 100 cases of COVID-19 were diagnosed in a day in London was May 7, when it was 149. That had halved to 52 by May 15.

item.title: Twitter users rage against Apple's 'triggering' iPhone commercial
item.description: An TV ad for the iPhone 11 begins with the sound of an iPhone alarm. Viewers are complaining about it on Twitter, calling it 'triggering' and saying the sound is 'cruel.'

item.title: Girl, 19, charged with perverting course of justice after telling police she was raped by Asian gang
item.description: WARNING GRAPHIC CONTENT: The teenager, from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, is currently in custody awaiting a court hearing, having allegedly breached her bail conditions.

item.title: Woman shares adorable moment her friend's dog meet's its sibling in the park
item.description: Libby Pincher, from Bishop Auckland, County Durham, took to Twitter to reveal her friend Dave had been in the park his poodle, when he saw another walker with a similar dog, and they ran to each other.

item.title: Coronavirus Russia: Chechen leader, a Putin ally, in hospital
item.description: Ramzan Kadyrov, 43, has been flown to hospital in Moscow from his regional capital Grozny with suspected coronavirus. Official sources say the Chechen strongman has a respiratory infection.

item.title: Girl, 14, dies and friend, 13, is rushed to hospital after 'taking ecstasy'
item.description: Emergency services were called to the property in Scarborough (pictured, a general view of the road) at about 4pm on Wednesday after the child started to feel unwell.

item.title: Coronavirus: South America is becoming the new epicentre
item.description: South America is now the world region where coronavirus cases are growing fastest with death rates also soaring as the continent rapidly becomes a the new epicentre of the virus.

item.title: JK Rowling started Harry Potter above Clapham sports shop
item.description: J.K. Rowling, 54, revealed on Twitter that she had already started writing the Harry Potter book series before she started visiting the Edinburgh café which is often regarded as the 'birthplace' the novels.

item.title: Scotland bans companies based in tax havens from using coronavirus relief funding
item.description: MSPs approved the move after measures were put forward by the Scottish Greens. Pictured: The British Crown dependency of Jersey, which has a reputation for being a tax haven.

item.title: Man gets revenge on van thief by hacking Facebook account
item.description: The tradesman, 40, from Manchester, who has asked to remain anonymous, logged into the would-be thief's Facebook profile on the phone and posted a series of hilarious statuses.

item.title: Coronavirus France: Sunbathers lie in social distancing zones
item.description: Sunbathers were lying on their towels in La Grande Motte (pictured today) where visitors can reserve a three-and-a-half-hour slot at the seaside.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Some hospitality business owners 'suicidal'
item.description: James Mason, chief executive of Welcome to Yorkshire, says the UK's £50billion international tourism industry could lose up to '90 per cent' of its trade if a 14 day quarantine is brought in.

item.title: Lib Dem peer apologises after furloughing himself
item.description: Lord Christopher Fox today admitted making an 'error of judgment' after he sparked a backlash and was accused of trying to 'milk the taxpayer at both ends'.

item.title: Venezuela warns America its navy will escort Iranian oil tankers
item.description: The tankers are carrying around 1.5 million barrels of fuel to the Latin American nation as it faces an acute scarcity of gasoline as the country endures the novel coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Crime falls by a QUARTER overall during coronavirus lockdown
item.description: The provisional data from all 43 forces in England and Wales shows a 25 per cent drop in overall crime, excluding fraud, in the four weeks to May 10.

item.title: China's infectious disease expert warns coronavirus will 'co-exist' with humans 'for a long time'
item.description: An expert from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention urged people to change their lifestyles to suit a new normality, which involves regular virus control.

item.title: China plans new laws to 'take full control of Hong Kong'
item.description: The bill would block secession, foreign interference, terrorism and all seditious activities aimed at toppling the central government and any external interference in the financial hub.
item.media:credit: South China Morning Post via Get

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 36,042 with 338 new fatalities
item.description: Today's statistics come as data shows the number of people being diagnosed with the virus each day in London has plummeted from more than 1,000 in April to fewer than 100 in May.

item.title: Sadiq Khan says he is considering making wearing face masks mandatory on the Tube and London buses
item.description: The London Mayor said he hopes to persuade the Government to change its position on the issue, but he has the option to 'make it mandatory in the capital only'.

item.title: One per cent of the population have 'thinness gene' and can eat what they want
item.description: In a clinical trial by the University of British Columbia, Canada, researchers looked at the genetic profile of 47,102 people aged 20 to 44 years old living in Estonia.

item.title: Local council zoom meeting boils over as grandmother brands peer 'absolutely thick'
item.description: A local council digital zoom meeting spilled over into a shouting match, after a retired grandmother and councillor of Shaftesbury Council burst into a furious tirade and branded her peers 'thick.'

item.title: Nigel Farage says NINE boats carrying migrants are already on the Channel this morning
item.description: The Brexit Party leader, 56, claimed today would be 'another record day' for crossings with nine migrant boats already reported to be on the Channel crossing the perilous Dover Strait shipping lane.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: How to use Superdrug's DIY antibody kit
item.description: Superdrug became the first British high-street retailer to launch an antibody test. Done at home, the test isn't unsafe. However, results may be skewed if the person doesn't do it correctly.

item.title: Jackie Kennedy Onassis' friend recalls the former First Lady's publishing career
item.description: Jackie Kennedy Onassis insisted on having a small office in the Doubleday New York HQ and resisted a pay rise, former boss Nancy Evans recalls in an essay published in new book One Last Lunch.

item.title: Species of frog size of 5p coin discovered in Madagascar
item.description: The new species of stump-toed frog, Stumpffia troschaueri, is brown in colour and was found in leaf litter lying on the floor of forests in Sahamalaza, north-west coast of Madagascar.
item.media:credit: Gonçalo M. Rosa, Angelica Crottini et al.

item.title: Heart-stopping moment driver of £92,000 Audi RS6 films himself hitting 201MPH
item.description: The Audi RS6 was filmed driving along the M23 in West Sussex at 201mph. The driver showed himself driving single handed while he documented the car's strong acceleration.

item.title: Woman wins £900,000 Picasso painting in Italian raffle
item.description: Claudia Borgogno, 58, an accountant from Ventimiglia, in northern Italy was announced as the winner of the charity raffle by organisers on Wednesday. Pictured; Organiser Peri Cochin.

item.title: If coronavirus cures us of the habit of buying stuff we will all end up happier, wealthier and wiser
item.description: JANET STREET-PORTER: I'm fed up with cooking and clearing up. I am sick of my partner moaning about his backache. I miss travelling.

item.title: Pictured: Russian nurse disciplined for wearing only underwear beneath see-through gown
item.description: Nurse Nadia, 23, was pictured wearing underwear under her PPE at Tula Regional Clinical Hospital. Now the head of Miss X lingerie brand has said she wants the nurse to model for them.

item.title: Mountain pony adopts three orphan lambs and even feeds them her own milk
item.description: Ten-year-old horse Heidi took on the care of the young trio following the death of their own mother. The mare is on loan to Becky Popham, who also bought the three sheep for her field in Somerset.

item.title: Brabus launches a £440,000 armoured Mercedes G-Wagen
item.description: The German luxury car tuner has taken a Mercedes G-Wagen and cladded it in armoured steel to create a blast-resistant SUV that will keep the most under-threat individuals safe.

item.title: Key worker and wife scoop £10,000-a-month in the National Lottery after buying ticket 'on a whim'
item.description: Rich Pearson, a 30-year-old key worker in the infrastructure sector, and wife Kim, 33, from Upminster in east London, matched the five main numbers and will now start hunting for a new house.

item.title: Fury as Boris Johnson ESCAPES criminal investigation on claims he gave 'mistress' special treatment
item.description: The Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) said on Thursday that it would not be launching a probe into the Prime Minister following claims of misconduct in public office, which he denies.

item.title: US approves sale of $180million worth of submarine-launched torpedoes to Taiwan
item.description: The US State Department notified Congress of the potential sale to Taiwan of 18 MK-48 Mod6 Advanced Technology Heavy Weight Torpedoes and related equipment on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince Charles will be the 'best prepared monarch we've ever had', royal expert claims
item.description: Prince Charles, 71, has the potential to 'divide opinion rather than unite it', suggestes British historian Piers Brendon on tonight's ITV documentary The Queen: Inside The Crown, which airs at 9pm.

item.title: Attention-seeking kitten slams owners's laptop screen shut to stop them from watching TV
item.description: A black-and-white kitten in Vladivostok, Russia, found an ingenious way to stop its owners watching TV and give it attention. A video from April 24 shows the kitten pounce on top of the laptop.

item.title: Can you be made redundant while on furlough? Firms axe staff
item.description: As big firms make redundancies, we have spoken to a number of furloughed workers who are now being told they will may lose their jobs

item.title: Keeping tomatoes in fridge does NOT impair flavour, study says
item.description: Researchers stored the favoured salad food at 44F and 68F before putting them to an expert panel of food assessors, who found no significant differences in sweetness, acidity and juiciness.

item.title: Almost 24 MILLION people entered the UK in the first three months of 2020 with no coronavirus checks
item.description: Some 23.7million 'passenger arrivals', including foreign visitors and Britons returning home, were clocked at UK sea and airports between January and March, the Home Office revealed.

item.title: Shoppers praise anti-ageing collection which sold one every 60 seconds during its launch week in UK
item.description: Beauty fans from across the nation have gone wild for PRAI's 24K Gold Wrinkle Repair collection - which sold one every 60 seconds during the launch week in the UK.

item.title: Accountant author of book on how to beat the taxman avoids jail after cheating HMRC out of £120,000
item.description: The 68-year-old from Portcawl wrote a book called The Taxpayer Strikes Back about how to 'stand up to' HMRC after leaving a Government job to go into accountancy, but soon came unstuck.

item.title: Primary schoolboy is seriously wounded after being flogged 1,500 TIMES by his guardians
item.description: The year-five student from eastern China's Zhejiang was whipped for hours with a wooden ruler and a metal coat hanger by a couple who were asked by the boy's mother to look after him full-time.

item.title: Britain has the HIGHEST rate of excess deaths in Europe
item.description: Around 55,000 more Britons than normal have died in 2020, up nearly 70 per cent compared to the five-year average. Belgium has suffered 9,000 excess deaths - 57 per cent higher than average.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon says Scots lockdown can loosen from next week
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon said Scotland can take the first cautious steps towards easing the draconian curbs from May 28, suggesting the loosening will go slightly further than in England.

item.title: Nurseries could 'divide children into close friendship groups' after lockdown
item.description: The UK's largest childcare provider Busy Bees, which has 378 centres across the country, has revealed its plans for welcoming children back after lockdown, including more outdoors play.

item.title: Rishi Sunak could ask businesses to pay National Insurance for furloughed workers
item.description: The Treasury said this week that there are now an estimated eight million workers who have been furloughed across the UK.

item.title: Number 10 denies Boris Johnson is having to rest and insists he is 'working as normal'
item.description: Although Mr Johnson took Prime Minister's Questions in the Commons yesterday, he has only taken the daily Downing Street press conference once since his recovery from Coronavirus.

item.title: Hagen Mills died after attempted murder-suicide in front of child
item.description: Hagen Mills begged his ex-girlfriend Erica Price to get back together before he shot her on Tuesday night in Mayfield, Kentucky, DailyMail.com has learned.

item.title: CDC says virus does not spread easily from contaminated surfaces
item.description: The agency added 'touching surfaces or objects' to the ways in which the coronavirus is not readily transmitted.

item.title: Aston Villa star Jack Grealish splashes out £25,000 on a guard dog after Dele Alli robbery
item.description: Grealish has become the latest star to use security firm Chaperone K9 and this week took a delivery of a Belgian Malinois. Marcus Rashford and Raheem Sterling have also used the company.

item.title: Britain sees worse economic slump than Sweden after imposing lockdown
item.description: Britain's GDP has already suffered a larger slump than Sweden's this year, with only one week of lockdown included in the figures so far.

item.title: Nigella Lawson shares her recipe for delicious chocolate chip cookies
item.description: Nigella Lawson, 60, took to Instagram and shared a recipe for chocolate chip cookies - and fans say it's the 'best' one they've ever tried.

item.title: Tony Slattery's partner says it's 'hard to care for someone who's always on the edge' in documentary
item.description: In a new BBC Two documentary airing tonight, What's the Matter with Tony Slattery? the London-born actor, 60, opens up about his mental health and substance abuse.

item.title: Dog groomer has to fend off a frisky bulldog humping her back as she clips its nails
item.description: Kali Lander, 21, was mounted while giving a doggy pedicure in Granbury, Texas. The groomer was filmed being rescued by a coworker on CCTV before bursting into laughter.

item.title: British bartender is found dead 'inside her wardrobe' in Magaluf
item.description: Danielle Finlay Brookes, 24, from Cheshire, who had been living and working in the Spanish party resort of Magaluf for several years as a bartender, was found dead in her flat Tuesday night.

item.title: Mysterious 'black goo' used by Ancient Egyptians to cover coffins identified by British Museum
item.description: Scientists at the British Museum analysed 100 samples of 'black goo' to establish its contents. It is thought Egyptians used it due to the black colour, which symbolised regeneration and rebirth.

item.title: Yazidis recount the harrowing tales of being kept as ISIS slaves
item.description: Investigators with the Commission for International Justice and Accountability are amassing evidence, hoping to prosecute IS figures for crimes against humanity.

item.title: EasyJet to resume flights from June 15
item.description: The low-cost carrier, which has been grounded since late March, said it would likely operate domestic flights only between 22 European airports, with more routes added when they became viable.

item.title: Air France permanently axes its A380 fleet with immediate effect
item.description: The superjumbo is close to the end of its production run after demand switched to smaller jets, and airlines have been idling the double-decker temporarily because of the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: Home Depot brawlers hurl paint over each other in bizarre fight in Florida
item.description: Four men were filmed fighting in a Tampa Home Depot car park yesterday. The men used garden tools and paint cans as weapons and continued to fight until they saw the camera.

item.title: Brother and sister who had to spend lockdown apart hug after not seeing each other for nine weeks
item.description: Siblings Lily Rudor, 11 and her step-brother Freddie, from the West Midlands, had not seen each other since before the lockdown, nine weeks ago and immediately embraced during a surprise walk.

item.title: UK frontline workers will be given hydroxychloroquine in clinical trial
item.description: Donald Trump has previously hailed hydroxychloroquine as a 'game changer,' in the fight against Covid-19, telling reporters earlier this week he had been taking the anti-malaria drug.

item.title: How the Kennedys closed ranks after Ted's Chappaquiddick scandal for letting Mary Jo Kopechne drown
item.description: New book Before Chappaquiddick, The Untold Story of Mary Jo Kopechne and the Kennedy Brothers takes a deeper look into Mary Jo's life and death, who died in 1996.
